column2:
A command that moves the cursor.
Examples:
  w		to start of next word
  b		to begin of current word
  4j		four lines down
  /The<CR>	to next occurrence of "The"

A pattern is one or more branches, separated by "\|".  It matches anything that matches one of the branches. A branch is one or more concats, separated by "\&".  It matches the last concat, but only if all the preceding concats also match at the same position. A concat is one or more pieces, concatenated.  It matches a match for the first piece, followed by a match for the second piece, etc. A piece is an atom, possibly followed by a multi, an indication of how many times the atom can be matched. An atom can be one of a long list of items.  Many atoms match one character in the text.  It is often an ordinary character or a character class. Braces can be used to make a pattern into an atom.

Note for systems other than Unix: When using a command that accepts a single file name (like ":edit file") spaces in the file name are allowed, but trailing spaces are ignored.  This is useful on systems that regularly embed spaces in file names (like MS-Windows and the Amiga).  Example: The command ":e   Long File Name " will edit the file "Long File Name".  When using a command that accepts more than one file name (like ":next file1 file2") embedded spaces must be escaped with a backslash.

At present this includes |:e|, |:w|, |:wall|, |:wq|, |:wqall|, |:x|, |:xall|, |:exit|, |:view|, |:sview|, |:r|, |:saveas|, |:sp|, |:mkexrc|, |:mkvimrc|, |:mksession|, |:mkview|, |:split|, |:vsplit|, |:tabe|, |:tabnew|, |:cfile|, |:cgetfile|, |:caddfile|, |:lfile|, |:lgetfile|, |:laddfile|, |:diffsplit|, |:diffpatch|, |:open|, |:pedit|, |:redir|, |:source|, |:update|, |:visual|, |:vsplit|, and |:qall| if 'confirm' is set.

It consists of one or more line specifiers, separated with ',' or ';'. For example, ':1,5s/this/that/g' executes the substitute command on the lines 1 to 5.  Line 5 is included. The range is always placed before the command.
